On Thu, 2005-06-02 at 09:06 -0700, Cedric Beust wrote:
> It is important to group your tests in various categories, which can
> represent several different things depending on your emphasis.  For example,
> you can have "database" tests, "front-end" tests, "security" tests, etc...

I strongly agree, and I think this is something important that is simply
missing from JUnit.

> Obviously, one test can belong to several tests.

...several groups(?)

> It was good enough back then because there was no choice, but we can do much
> better now with annotations:
> 
> @Test(groups = { "check-in", "functional", "database" })

Or you can use marker interfaces to the same purpose:

public class FooTest implements NeedsDatabaseTest, FunctionalTest { ... }

and simply have a test collector that finds all of the classes that
include or exclude particular marker interfaces.  How are annotations
superior to just using interfaces like that?
